24553: Excise.author: GrimjawxRULES
24553: Excise.text_parsed:
Seperates the good from the bad: New players tend to play their creatures and other spells on their first main phase, while more skilled players will wait until their second main phase, leaving mana open during the combat phase to feign pressure. This means that newer players will be less likely to have mana open to pay the x-cost, while more skilled players will usually have the mana to do so.

Other than that, I assume this is pretty good against a deck sporting a lot of creatures with haste, as your opponent is more likely to be playing those spells on their first main phase.

24557: Entangler.author: KingSupernova
24557: Entangler.text_parsed:
@bigbazukabo

Your numbers are a little messed up. Yavimaya Enchantress with those enchantments on her will be 4/4, not 6/6. Blastoderm is only a 5/5. And 64 minus 6 equals 58, not 62. Also Blastoderm doesn't have trample.

To answer your question, a 6/6 blocking 8 8/8 tramplers will soak up damage equal to its toughness (6) leaving the rest (58) to go through. Also, putting Inviolability on the creature doesn't affect how much damage goes through, it just changes whether the creature dies or not.

24559: Reveille Squad.author: Aremath
24559: Reveille Squad.text_parsed:
To those of you saying you wish it had flash:
It's a REBEL.

Overall, I like the way it works, but it's not playable under most normal circumstances. Furthermore, if you're relying on this to be able to block with your tapped dudes, you can get blown out big-time by a removal spell.

Might work well in Derevi, Empyrial Tactician EDH however. There you have the ability to untap it after combat so that its ability will still happen later on, and you get to abuse its ability with all the other {T} abilities in the deck. And you get to do it for each player at the table, making it a pretty big disincentive to swing at you.

Unlike many other cards, it has combo potential, and neat intricacies of its abilities that make it more interesting than it seems at first.

It's a [i]REBEL[/i].

Overall, I like the way it works, but it's not playable under most normal circumstances. Furthermore, if you're relying on this to be able to block with your tapped dudes, you can get blown out big-time by a removal spell.

Might work well in [autocard]Derevi, Empyrial Tactician[/autocard] EDH however. There you have the ability to untap it after combat so that its ability will still happen later on, and you get to abuse its ability with all the other {T} abilities in the deck. And you get to do it for each player at the table, making it a pretty big disincentive to swing at you.

Unlike many other cards, it has combo potential, and neat intricacies of its abilities that make it more interesting than it seems at first.

24560: Aura Fracture.author: Prizrak
24560: Aura Fracture.text_parsed:
Land sacrifice isn't necessarily bad. Use it in response to yourself casting Planar Birth to trigger even more landfall (targeting itself if need be). Or think up something crazy with cards like Furnace Celebration and Jinxed Ring. Or mitigate the penalty and thin your deck with Knight of the White Orchid type effects.

For sillier ideas because they're fun to think up, get a reliable way to play an enchantment to kill every turn and use Limited Resources to give yourself the advantage in a landfall vs. landfall matchup. Or throw it in if you really hate your friend's Gilt-Lief Archdruid deck and want to irritate them? o_O

24561: Abolish.author: Internet_decks_lame
24561: Abolish.text_parsed: This card should be rated much higher then what it appears to be. In the older formats (such as legacy, or vintage) there are so many decks that are designed to lock out the opponent in the first 2 turns, if it has not already stole the game by generating a ludicrous storm count. If you are a regular magic player in these older formats, you will always need to keep an eye open for spells that have replacement effects for general casting. Now although this card may not be ideal against a storm player, it should generally be very useful against any other annoying lock based deck; Counter-Top, Trinisphere, and I am sure you may know of a few others if you are an avid player. Most lock designed decks need either an artifact or an enchantment to create the such. And at worst, you still get a 3 mana disenchant, well at first glance may seem inferior to white's staple disenchant, although this spell being 3 cmc may improve your chances of going around the lovely and ever so annoying Counterbalance. Most counter balance decks will have a very limitied amount of 3 cmc cards, and if they do have 3 cmc cards, then its good chances the deck will be tri-color, and be far more susceptible to cards like Blood Moon & Magus of the Moon.

24561: Abolish.author: Kirbster
24561: Abolish.text_parsed: I find Abolish is great for backing up the Equipoise/Sands of Time combo. Those two can remove all of your opponent's creatures and most of his lands, but don't touch enchantments and are less effective against artifacts if you're using artifact mana to get around the land restriction. Since you'll have lands accruing in your hand from not playing them, Abolish lets you use them to remove artifacts or enchantments on your opponent's side that the Equipoise misses! What lovely synergy.

I don't know about a lot of downsides, but it's safe to say that probably over 90% of your rare creatures are shroudless and therefore suffer creature removal, so if that's the biggest peeve, well, he is white and white has plenty of instant and or enchantments for color protection. I found the easiest way to cancel out the Spellshaper Legends from the Prophecy series was to just run Squee Goblins for negating the discard effect. Anyway, Madness comes into play not too much further down the road, and a creature that can wrath/trigger 2 choice discards works fine for madness, threshold, lhurgoyf's, Judgement's Incarnations....  Anyway with that kind of versatility I can't help but favor it over the new Mythic Novablast Wurm.  Not to mention the fact that Mageta includes a "cannot be regenerated" with its destroy ability.

24567: Celestial Convergence.author: sonorhC
24567: Celestial Convergence.text_parsed:
There are plenty of ways to end a Magic game in a draw. If something does damage to you and your opponent at the same time (say, Earthquake or Pestilence), that can be a draw. If you both have empty libraries and something causes you to both draw at the same time (Jace Beleren, maybe), that can be a draw. If you both have Platinum Angels keeping you alive while you're both at negative life or >10 poison counters and something kills both angels at once, that's a draw. Anything that causes loss conditions to trigger for both players at once is a draw.

Plus there's also draw by infinite loop, but that doesn't come up very often.
24567: Celestial Convergence.text_posted:
There are plenty of ways to end a Magic game in a draw.  If something does damage to you and your opponent at the same time (say, [autocard]Earthquake[/autocard] or [autocard]Pestilence[/autocard]), that can be a draw.  If you both have empty libraries and something causes you to both draw at the same time ([autocard]Jace Beleren[/autocard], maybe), that can be a draw.  If you both have [autocard]Platinum Angel[/autocard]s keeping you alive while you're both at negative life or >10 poison counters and something kills both angels at once, that's a draw.  Anything that causes loss conditions to trigger for both players at once is a draw.

Plus there's also draw by infinite loop, but that doesn't come up very often.

24567: Celestial Convergence.author: DarthParallax
24567: Celestial Convergence.text_parsed:
Worldfire + Barren Glory + Near-Death Experience + 2 Oblivion Rings

or Karn Liberated + Celestial Convergence + Vampire Hexmage + Felidar Sovereign + some way to do 1 damage to everyone :

OR Combo A + Celestial Convergence + Oblivion Ring #3 + Vampire Hexmage + Oblivion Ring + 4 + Some way that taps with haste to do damage to everyone else + Copy Enchantment #1

*It's impossible to have exactly 40, 50, and 1 life at the same time. That's why I'm not mentioning Test of Endurance, and why you can't automatically win in EVERY way POSSIBLE at the same time. We will also not bother trying to Infect our opponents on top of this....whatever...thingy.*

1. Worldfire sets you up for Barren Glory and Near-Death Experience. The Oblivion Ring combo will ensure they survive and come back. We'll be abusing Oblivion Ring with Copy Enchantment for the 3rd way.

2. Karn can reset the game, in Commander you start with 40 life, Vampire Hexmage can remove the counters on this, Karn removes those 3 permanents and your start with them all at the beginning of the game. If you have Karn remove some 4th thing that allows you to instantly bring everyone down to 39, you'll have more life, a Celestial Convergence with no counters, and exactly 40 life with a Felidar Sovereign.

3. (4. This is the dumbest thing you can do ever. You might as well throw in a Tinker, a way to bring back and cast Tinker again, a Door to Nothingness a Mox Lotus, and a Sol Ring to sac twice to your Tinkers with the artifact bringer-backer-thingy ON TOP of what I'm about to write if you're doing this in a Duel):

OK. Here goes.

Copy Enchantment gives us virtually 8 Oblivion Rings. We can use Oblivion Rings to set up our Worldfire so that we return:
Near-Death Experience (not using Soveriegn for this one, BUT..)
Barren Glory
Vampire Hexmage
Celestial Convergence (that's 4 Oblivion Rings used up)
if the thing you are going to ping everyone with is a permanent, say an Izzet card that can Overload from Return to Ravnica? or a spell with Overload on an Isochron Scepter?
you can exile it with ANOTHER Oblivion Ring by Copy Enchantment.
You can bring that back at the same time as the rest, and it will bring everyone to 0, and you will be at 1 courtest of Worldfire, and you will win by:

Having more life (CC)
Having no cards and no permanents (BG)
Having 1 life (NDE)
AND everyone being a 0 life (Win)

If you used some retarded thing to splice that Doorway to Nothingness combo in, then you can probably use this with Shaharazad and Mindslaver.

Hell, why don't we throw Griselbrand and Necropotence into this instead of Tinker, so that our color identities can be in Kaalia of the Vast and we can lose ABSOLUTELY EVERYONE of our friends at once??

24567: Celestial Convergence.author: Jankin
24567: Celestial Convergence.text_parsed: It's false that in 2 player matches earthquake or simultaneous effects cause a draw. In a 1v1 match, the player triggering the effect loses first. So if you're both at 5 and you earthquake or pestilence for 5, you both die, but you lose. In multiplayer it doesn't matter as much as long as 1 player survives.
24567: Celestial Convergence.text_posted: It's false that in 2 player matches earthquake or simultaneous effects cause a draw. In a 1v1 match, the player triggering the effect loses first. 24568: Sheltering Prayers.author: roguepariah
24568: Sheltering Prayers.text_parsed:
In Prophecy this wasn't such a bad card. Still isn't if someone keeps hosing you with land destruction in casual games.

Prophecy had tons of cards that asked you to sacrifice lands. It also included some land destruction. If you wanted to sacrifice lands to pay for abilities (like Squirrel Wrangler) and your opponent played Keldon Arsonist, well, you were screwed. It also worked in-set with things like Living Terrain. Sacrifice land to any number of abilities available and give your 5/6 forest shroud.

I don't particularly like the design of Prophecy, but I can see why this card made it to print.

24568: Sheltering Prayers.author: blurrymadness
24568: Sheltering Prayers.text_parsed:
Potentially good sideboard against *very* efficient land removal. If someone starts locking you down with Raze, Sinkhole, ritual'd LD, or similar; you don't have 3 mana for Crucible of Worlds, Terra Eternal or similar. You get 1 mana.

This is one of the few cards (if not the only one) that allows your white-weenie to continue unhindered. Remember that the deck locking you down *is* making their land drops and *is* working towards a win con. Completely hosing their deck is an effective strategy IMO.

24571: Ribbon Snake.author: Kruzewah
24571: Ribbon Snake.text_parsed:
The only good thing about this card are the mind games it plays on the opponent...
--Opponent plays Ribbon snake--
"Should I save the mana?"
"I should build my army."
--Smacked for 2--
"Should I save the mana?"
"I think I can take it again."
--Plays spell that gets cancelled--
"Crap"
--Smacked for 2--
"Should I save the mana?"
"Whatever, I'm still above fifteen, right?"
--Plays spell that gets undermined--
"Lame"
--Smacked for 2--
"Should I save the mana?"
"I think I'll save my mana and creatures to kill that stupid snake!"
--Opponent gets some inspiration--
--Opponent plays another ribbon snake--
"Either play something or get smacked for 4"
"Well, let's stick to plan B...do nothing...."
--Opponent plays sleep--
"Screw you"
--Smacked for 4--

.......and it keeps going like that

24580: Withdraw.author: holgir

24580: Withdraw.author: Mode
24580: Withdraw.text_parsed:
I think this card is currently underrated.
At worst it's a plain Unsummon for .
Bouncing two for two mana is a great deal if it works out.
On top of that it's even more useful when used in a self-bounce deck, since the controler and not just any player may pay to prevent that effect.
Therefore you can always either decide to Rescue two of your creatures, or return one of your opponent and one of yours.

@Maraxas
You don't mean that! There's always the beloved Branded Brawlers and Veteran Brawlers. If nothing else, they're great fun to make a big deal about when you play :P

I like the card, and i feel the 3.5 stars does it justice. Boomerang any day for me. I just don't like card that only target creatures, though... I guess I still like black/white removal.. I don't know. It feels like in blue there's potentially better ways to be a nuisance. Bounce is always tempo advantage for card disadvantage and that's a hard thing to weigh against.

24580: Withdraw.author: yyukichigai
24580: Withdraw.text_parsed:
I use this card in an oddball Wall deck I built using a number of deliberately "low-quality" cards. It's remarkably effective, though I almost always use it in one specific way: bouncing one of my creatures while I bounce one of my opponent's at the same time. I think there's only been one time when I ever managed to bounce two opposing creatures at once. This is not a bad thing: for sure the card has always met my needs.

For two Unsummons stapled together this isn't bad at all, even with the possibility of one of the creatures not being bounced. I think Wizards could have gotten away with making this cost {1}{U} because of that possibility, but even at {U}{U} this is a good card to run in any deck where you expect to be doing a lot of bouncing.

24580: Withdraw.author: RaymondKHessel
24580: Withdraw.text_parsed:
Ahh, Withdraw. One of the many underrated cards in the much-maligned Prophecy expansion. Along with the excellent Curfew, this is one of my favorite bounce spells in the game.

All the comments above have really gotten the key points: you needn't wait for your opponent to tap out to get effective use of the card, though bouncing two of your opponent's creatures for 2 is excellent. Bounce their creature then bounce your own (by electing not to pay the 1) either in response to a hostile spell or recharge an ETB creature. Lots of fun ways to use the card.

@tavaritz: definitely a good point, there. Withdraw shouldn't be equated with Unsummon.

24581: Spiketail Hatchling.author: Paolino
24581: Spiketail Hatchling.text_parsed:
My spiketail drakes rating.
1) Drakeling. Three mana for a 2/2 flier is already at the standard; with a countering ability which makes opponent's dangerous spells more expensive it's really good!
2) Hatchling. Yes, Hatchling. I must say that I like it, even if it's not that all-good card. But it's cheap, it flies, it can chump-block and it can prevent some powerful spells to be played early due to their practically higher casting cost.
3) Drake. It's very expensive, but a 3/3 flier is always a good creature, and more is a prohibitive cost to pay for most of the spells opponent could play that could be a serious menace for you. However, its casting cost puts it on the bottom of the table.

24583: Stormwatch Eagle.author: jfre81
24583: Stormwatch Eagle.text_parsed:
Storm Crow, memes aside, is not a bad card. It's often described as average, but a 1/2 two-drop with flying is quite efficient by traditional blue standards.
This costs twice the mana as Storm Crow and isn't a significant upgrade. Even in blue, hopefully you're playing something better than a 2/1 bird with a land-sack self-bounce. Now, if it was "sack a land = bounce target creature" then we're talking about something that would make an impact in the mid/late game. They still print Unsummon for a reason. All this thing does is allow you to bring it back to pay too much mana for it all over again.

24587: Foil.author: Plum
24587: Foil.text_parsed:
I actually really like this in my Madness deck.
In that situation in gets close to the same level as Force of Will in terms of power.

It functions as a Madness outlet, and a free counter. Force of Will on the other hand exiles the card.
I would say its better if it weren't for the fact that you had to have an island in hand to play it. Though I also run Daze in the deck, so it's not too hard to accomplish that. There are times where I use this and then don't see another land for a few turns, which is why Force of Will is still better.

However the look on my opponent's face when I play this and then pop in my Basking Rootwalla or Arrogant Wurm is great. It also works well when you toss a Wonder into your grave, or something like Quiet Speculation. The kind of cards that you want in your grave anyways.

With creativity its possible to make this poor man's Force of Will much better than seems.

24587: Foil.author: Travelsonic
24587: Foil.text_parsed:
When talking Foil versus Force of Will, I like how the mana cost seems to be what a few - not everyone, obviously - are harping on.

Sure, for hardcasting, FoW is better.

What about the alternative-to-paying-the-mana-cost?

Would you rather lose life and exile a blue permanent, or discard an island, and another card - a land, a creature with the madness ability, or something that is either useful in the graveyard, can be brought back somehow easily, etc?

Ultimately it depends, I for one don't want to run the risk of losing mana sources just to counter a spell, but from discussions online **in general** I don't think Foil is being given enough credit... sure, it is no FoW, but there **MAY** be potentials I don't think are being realized with this card that you can't necessarily do with FoW directly.
24587: Foil.text_posted:

Would you rather lose life and exile a blue permanent, or discard an island, and another card - a land, a creature with the madness ability, or something that is either useful in the graveyard, can be brought back somehow easily, etc?   

Ultimately it depends, I for one don't want to run the risk of losing mana sources just to counter a spell, but from discussions online **in general** I don't think Foil is being given enough credit... sure, it is no FoW, but there **MAY** be potentials I don't think are being realized with this card that you can't necessarily do with FoW directly.

24588: Rethink.author: Ragamander
24588: Rethink.text_parsed:
This is an interesting card. While not at all reliable, it scales to the size of the threat. The bigger the spell, the bigger the challenge it is to overcome Rethink.

I'm not sure it's playable, though. If others know you're playing it, on the other hand, they might try to leave open twice as much mana as they need for things, slowing them down significantly for the rest of the game (whereas something like Mana Leak would only slow them down towards the beginning of the game).

24589: Rhystic Study.author: Lyoncet
24589: Rhystic Study.text_parsed:
One of my favorite things about this card is that it makes it really hard for your opponent to get any card advantage once it comes down. If they're only drawing one per turn, by turn 3 they may or may not be able to pay that extra 1 without much problem. But if they're constantly replenishing their hand, they'll almost always either have to sit on the extra cards or forfeit their advantage.

Even if they're not running much in the way of draw, it's really unlikely that this card won't at least be able to replicate itself if not give you an early advantage. And at a very splashable 3 CMC, it's hard to see a case where this won't end up in your favor.
24589: Rhystic Study.text_posted:
One of my favorite things about this card is that it makes it really hard for your opponent to get any card advantage once it comes down.  If they're only drawing one per turn, by turn 3 they may or may not be able to pay that extra 1 without much problem.  But if they're constantly replenishing their hand, they'll almost always either have to sit on the extra cards or forfeit their advantage.

Even if they're not running much in the way of draw, it's really unlikely that this card won't at least be able to replicate itself if not give you an early advantage.  And at a very splashable 3 CMC, it's hard to see a case where this won't end up in your favor.

24589: Rhystic Study.author: GlassJoetheChamp
24589: Rhystic Study.text_parsed: Question here: Let's say I have this on the field and the opponent plays a spell, and I want to count with a Mana Leak or something. Could I still counter after this ability takes place, or do I counter beforehand?
24589: Rhystic Study.text_posted: Question here: Let's say I have this on the field and the opponent plays a spell, and I want to count with a [autocard]Mana Leak[/autocard] or something. Could I still counter after this ability takes place, or do I counter beforehand?

24589: Rhystic Study.author: Pinto331
24589: Rhystic Study.text_parsed:
@GlassJoetheChamp

Yes, you would counter after this ability goes on the stack. This ability is triggered when they cast the spell, not when it resolves. So the stack would look like this;

Their spell -> Rhystic Study's ability -> Mana Leak

They would first choose whether or not to pay 1 for this, then you would counter it.

24589: Rhystic Study.author: AmericanVigor
24589: Rhystic Study.text_parsed:
While it's a fun card, its effectiveness is overrated, especially when facing opponents with significant mana acceleration.

While the main purpose of this card is to draw more cards, the secondary, more frequently implemented purpose of this card is to make your opponents' spells cost {1} more if they do not want to incur a new penalty. By about each opponent's fifth turn in Commander games, the overall effectiveness of this card drastically drops because opponents can have far more ability to cast their desired spells of the turn and still "pay the {1}".

At that time, Rhystic Study's deterrent effect indubitably still influences spent mana, although for many players, this becomes rather inconsequential to their overall plans from their fifth turn and forward. Rhystic Study then largely sits on the board without consequence or benefit to its controller.

Rhystic Study's card draw benefit can be very beneficial at all times in which a new card is acquired, but cards drawn from Rhystic Study are most likely to be drawn early in the game, when opponents want to establish board position and don't care about deterring the card draw. Because Rhystic Study typically is cast on Turn 3 (or Turn 2, if one has used mana acceleration cards), its window of effective card draw benefit is limited.

24590: Avatar of Will.author: DoctorKenneth
24590: Avatar of Will.text_parsed:
I'm always a fan of the Avatar cycle. While it does feel a little Black, I understand that they wanted to design this Avatar with a cards-in-hand vibe, as the Avatar of Woe went with the cards-in-graveyard feel, which was more distinctly black. Cards-in-hand seems like a very blue feature, but there's a lot of things they COULDN'T do with that direction. If they made it trigger off of you having no cards in your hand, that'd be a more Red hand-emptying strategy. If they had it trigger off of you or an opponent having a larger number of cards in hand, it becomes incredibly easy for it to trigger. This was the simplist option for the design.

Also, yes, rk post is awesome.

24592: Spiketail Drake.author: Paolino
24592: Spiketail Drake.text_parsed:
My spiketail drakes rating.
1) Drakeling. Three mana for a 2/2 flier is already at the standard; with a countering ability which makes opponent's dangerous spells more expensive it's really good!
2) Hatchling. Yes, Hatchling. I must say that I like it, even if it's not that all-good card. But it's cheap, it flies, it can chump-block and it can prevent some powerful spells to be played early due to their practically higher casting cost.
3) Drake. It's very expensive, but a 3/3 flier is always a good creature, and more is a prohibitive cost to pay for most of the spells opponent could play that could be a serious menace for you. However, its casting cost puts it on the bottom of the table.
24592: Spiketail Drake.text_posted:
My spiketail drakes rating.
1) [autocard multiverseid="118913"]Drakeling[/autocard]. Three mana for a 2/2 flier is already at the standard; with a countering ability which makes opponent's dangerous spells [2] more expensive it's really good!
2) [autocard multiverseid="24581"]Hatchling[/autocard]. Yes, Hatchling. I must say that I like it, even if it's not that all-good card. But it's cheap, it flies, it can chump-block and it can prevent some powerful spells to be played early due to their practically higher casting cost.
3) [autocard multiverseid="24592"]Drake[/autocard]. It's very expensive, but a 3/3 flier is always a good creature, and [3] more is a prohibitive cost to pay for most of the spells opponent could play that could be a serious menace for you. However, its [3][U][U] casting cost puts it on the bottom of the table.

24592: Spiketail Drake.author: Sothasil
24592: Spiketail Drake.text_parsed: Not bad for a "big" drake. It's a bit easier to lock your opponent out of 3 mana rather than 2. Still, for the time it takes to drop this vs spiketail, I don't think it's worth it. Having mana leak built into your creatures is already going to make people play more conservatively, your opponent will either play spells as counter bait or make sure they have enough to tap for what they want to get through. I think 2 mana is usually more than enough to get the job done, as I usually end up using my spiketails as last line counters after forcing an opponent to tap out w/ a mana leak or when countering my counterspell. Just sac and counter again.

24596: Denying Wind.author: Nakriel
24596: Denying Wind.text_parsed:
I actually quite like this in EDH. It's pretty good for getting rid of certain cards that you'd prefer not to deal with, and it's pretty castable in that format in the right deck.
Things that come to mind for exile: Eldrazi, Praetor's Counsel, Iona.
Hell, you can even do it on yourself if your General has been Spell Crumple'd and you want to thin your deck of land in the late game.
Sadistic Sacrament is obviously better, but this has the advantage of being in blue, which has more spell copying stuff, and the General finding aspect of it is better in blue, which has less tutor than black.

24601: Agent of Shauku.author: Equinox523
24601: Agent of Shauku.text_parsed: Not as horrid as it looks at first glance.  The fact that you can tap those lands before sacrificing them, and that you can use the ability as many times as you can afford per turn, means this can enable sudden pump to push through the last points of damage you need to win.  This is particularly relevant in infect decks, which only need 10 damage to win - especially those with double strikers.

24605: Soul Strings.author: Gabriel422
24605: Soul Strings.text_parsed:
At first sight, this mechanic pretty rather interesting. And then you realize that it rewards people for playing draw-go, since if you tap out on your own turn you get punished by cards like this, and draw-go decks is one of the biggest thing they want to discourage people from playing nowadays.

If this were an instant though, it might be a different story. Well also assuming this was buffed a bit more.

24608: Steal Strength.author: Sharu
24608: Steal Strength.text_parsed:
I like this card.
It's a nice suprise to people, and turn the tide in one or two combats, even kill a lone little blocker and hit for an additional point of damage (fun finisher).

Reprinted in green, where I think it's not quite as good, as green is expected to use combat tricks a bit more than black, but still good.
Ther's more powerful versions tin two colours, such as the aforementioned Zealous Persecution, and a double power green-black version ( the name elludes me), which is happily cast by drooling groodion.

A solid, versatile card.
3.5/5

24614: Rhystic Tutor.author: jfre81
24614: Rhystic Tutor.text_parsed:
Opening draw in my casual, non-Standard (but perfectly Vintage-legal) B/U deck last night: this, two swamps, island, two Dark Rituals, Hypnotic Specter and Lotus Petal.

Turn 1: Swamp, Ritual, Rhystic Tutor. Hello, Liliana Vess. Make yourself at home in my hand, miss.
Turn 2: Swamp, Lotus Petal, sack it, out comes the Specter.
Turn 3: Island, then Ritual for Ms. Vess. Specter swings. Two discard with Lili's +1 ability, or settle for one discard from Specter and I can -2 and tutor for Necropotence. Later, counters, bounces and black creature removal for anything that threatens Liliana as I build her up with discards and proliferate, then I win with opponent's dead creatures a few turns later.
24614: Rhystic Tutor.text_posted:
Opening draw in my casual, non-Standard (but perfectly Vintage-legal) B/U deck last night: this, two swamps, island, two Dark Rituals, [autocard]Hypnotic Specter[/autocard] and [autocard]Lotus Petal[/autocard].

24617: Rebel Informer.author: NARFNra
24617: Rebel Informer.text_parsed:
The actual point of this card against rebel decks is pretty simple, guys. You know how they can recruit things from their library? See, that requires 1: Mana and 2: Tapping the "recruiter".What you're supposed to do is deal with things that were put out there for more than {3} mana, essentially giving you the advantage, perhaps for long enough to deal with their deck and win. And if all else fails, at least the recruiter and the recruited won't be attacking before you can toss them into their deck.

Oh, and since this guy doesn't tap for the ability, you could conceivably just put all of their recruiters away and laugh. Just don't mess with a Big Game Hunter.

24617: Rebel Informer.author: Velociraptors
24617: Rebel Informer.text_parsed:
Decent card nowadays. I run it in an enhanced rebel deck, the enhancements being Mirror Entity, Training Grounds and Amoeboid Changeling. You can use rebels to tutor this guy out, then tutor out Amoeboid Changeling with another rebel and you have targeted removal for 3 colorless, or 1 if you have a training grounds out. Tap Amoeboid Changeling to give an opponent's creature all creature types, then use this to put it on the bottom of their library.

Alternatively, this + Training Grounds + Shields of Velis Vel (used on an opponent) means you can remove multiple creatures at 1 colorless mana a pop. Decent combo card.

24617: Rebel Informer.text_parsed:
What I like about this card is that his name (and flavor text) are deliberately ambiguous, as is his ability.

Is he an informer who leaks information to the rebels, saving them from death? Or does he inform on the rebels, resulting in them getting disappeared? It can go either way.
24617: Rebel Informer.text_posted:
What I like about this card is that his name (and flavor text) are deliberately ambiguous, as is his ability.

Is he an informer who leaks information to the rebels, saving them from death?  Or does he inform [i]on[/i] the rebels, resulting in them getting disappeared?  It can go either way.

24619: Greel, Mind Raker.author: jam_marie
24619: Greel, Mind Raker.text_parsed: It's an interesting mentality that works really hard to build a deck around something like this--you want to play a card game with other people, the point of which is to see fantastic things and interesting synergies, but you also want to prevent any of that from ever happening and just skip to the part where you win. I find it unrewarding to play that way, but I like that it's an option; the execution of black as a color reflects the flavor of black mana so well.

24621: Avatar of Woe.author: Adromalath
24621: Avatar of Woe.text_parsed: This card always makes me nostalgic. When I was like 10, my best friends bigger brother introduced my friend and me to Magic. We learned the rules and made some crappy decks (I think I had Kavu deck...oh god) and played for the lulz. But then one day the older brother brought a friend of his to the game, and he was a serious pro. At least we thought so, I still remember when he showed me this card. I couldn't believe it, it was the coolest thing I had ever seen. I managed to talk him into trading me one (I'm sure he had multiples) and it's been one of my favorites ever since.

24624: Infernal Genesis.author: sarroth
24624: Infernal Genesis.text_parsed: Seems black to me: Like with Bitterblossom, black is willing to sacrifice its resources for small advantages through tokens. With Bitterblossom it was life, here it is a mill effect. You have to do it, and you have no idea if you are going to have a land milled or a huge creature - sometimes it'd be nice to have Draco hit the graveyard, sometimes maybe it'd be better to have a flying creature than a bunch of tiny tokens. Risking that for potentially large gains is very black.

Ugly, ugly art, though.

Here is a neat trick you could do. After he deals the first strike damage, use his ability. He will then do normal damage as well. Effectively making it double strike if your opponent doesn't do anything about it.

Newer cards like Jor Kadeen, the Prevailer also show that the theme of rebel is and (as well as the whole SoM block did - being the least phyrexian colors)

The oppressing side of red shown in this card is just another form of the concept of the bully which is quite a broad concept among red creatures.

But i agree that both this card and rebels could have switched colors.

24635: Brutal Suppression.author: Etsap
24635: Brutal Suppression.text_parsed:
@Ideatog
Turn 1: Brutal Suppression.
Turn 2: Unnatural Selection.
Turn 3+: all opponent's activated abilities are useless.

This doesn't work as well as you think. If you target their creature with Unnatural Selection after they activate the ability, then it does nothing. If you target their creature before they activate the ability, then they can just activate it in response so you've still done nothing. All this really does is allows you to control when they activate the ability, not what it's actually going to cost. Artificial Evolution on the other hand could actually accomplish what you want, but only for one of your opponent's creature types at a time.

24636: Scoria Cat.author: JarieSuicune
24636: Scoria Cat.text_parsed:
People that complain about Mana Burn's removal breaking cards like this, then using this as a "good example"... seem to have adjusted too far into the modern plays.
This card is a BAD example of Mana Burn support. Anyone who is going to use this is already designing their deck to take advantage of wanting to dump their mana either early or in one swell foop!
Simple (and obvious) combo:
Cast Scroria Cat, then cast Firebreathing on it. Give it Trample in any way, then solo rush and tap out for an easy 15/15+ smackdown that can face and eat Emrakul, the Aeons Torn with relative ease.
Running Mana Flare just made that even safer. And never subjected the player to any risk of Mana Burn. That massive attack, by the way, would be a turn 5 rush at the very latest.

24638: Branded Brawlers.author: Mode
24638: Branded Brawlers.text_parsed:
In Eternal Formats there are better choices, with dual lands (Tundra, Stomping Ground) and Fetchlands, getting a 2/3 Kird Ape on turn one will be much easier than keeping these guys in use.
For tribal i'd probably go for an Elite Vanguard instead.

They aren't that bad nonetheless if you build a deck around them, i'd probably run Rishadan Ports, Wastelands and further cards than can either tap or destroy your opponent's lands.

I prefer Veteran Brawers, you also don't get a 4/4 for two as often as a 2/2 for one. Also he doesn't die to Lightning Bolts. (And he can get cheaper with a Daru Warchief out or can kill Goyfs unharmed with Field Marshal :P)

@nimzo: Given the card read something around the lines like
"Branded Brawlers can't be casted if you don't control an untapped permanent that could produce red mana",
this would actually mean a further restriction since once you tapped your only mountain for mana, you don't have any untapped mana source left so the brawlers couldn't be cast ;)

24638: Branded Brawlers.author: RaymondKHessel
24638: Branded Brawlers.text_parsed: Veteran Brawlers are superior, but I'll try defending the Branded Brawlers here. I like them (and use them in a mono-red tap-out deck) because they force your opponent to make tough decisions in the early game. Early-game spells frequently stretch mana resources to the limit, and these guys force your opponent to either tap out and get socked each turn with a totally expendable and cheap 2/2 or effectively play a turn behind for the first couple turns. In the tap-out deck they're attackers early and then can get thrown away as blockers in the mid- and late-game. I'm not saying they're great, but a one mana 2/2 in red automatically gets my attention.

24640: Inflame.author: ubii
24640: Inflame.text_parsed:
This card is amazing...

Some examples:
1) Burn a few creatures and stack 2 damage onto choice targets. Makes arc lightning my best friend xD 9 damage four colourless
2) Offensively, with your weenies and when he blocks you use this to mop up his mid sized creatures. Also great as a deterrant.
3) Defensively, use with your chump blockers and light up all the attackers.
4) Use something that does one damage to everything... then use this to destroy anything less than 3 toughness on the board. A clean slate potentially deal 9 damage to all creatures and only one damage to players.
5) Gets around not being target of spells or abilities.
6) Combine with Repercussion for crazy fun.

Best way to amplify ANY damage in ANY turn since it's an instant <3 LOVE the way it saves the rest of the burn cards in my hand for where I really need them. Always run four in any burn deck.

24641: Search for Survivors.author: DoctorKenneth
24641: Search for Survivors.text_parsed:
I don't know, Mode. This kind of sparks in me the desire to create a mono-red deck with no non-creatures, non-lands at all (save for this, of course). It would be abominable, of course, but some part of me wants that to work. You would pack it with creature-inclusive removal like Flametounge Kavu to make up for the lack of burn (A red deck without burn? Odd how foriegn the concept seems to me). And, as mentioned, extra shots with Ball Lightning. I don't think this would be something you could use in a standard reanimation deck- if you're filling the graveyard with select fatties, you're going to be running black anyway (if only for the Entombs). And there's just so much better for the cost in black.

Red is just....bad at this sort of thing, I guess. And is it just me, or does this flavour seem more white? Not the random selection, as that's very red, but the fact that you're going back and looking for fallen comrades. Would red really care about the dead, other than to scavenge? It's more of a "live in the now" colour. I think it'd probably pack up camp and move on.

24643: Citadel of Pain.author: Havens
24643: Citadel of Pain.text_parsed:
I actually think this is still useful, despite there being no mana burn.

Think about it in a burn deck, versus.. say a blue player, or maybe even any player. At the end of their turn, they either take damage so they can counter your spells that will deal damage OR they dont take damage, then are unable to counter your spells that will deal them damage.

For a burn deck, this does 2 possible things that you want to see. they take damage or are tapped out. And when they do tap out, you can cast those big spells without worry of counter (unless they run force of will in a casual environment,.....)

24643: Citadel of Pain.author: superboi
24643: Citadel of Pain.text_parsed:
I was sorting cards, and saw this and thought to myself, well this is trash now. Then I thought about how it can be used.

This card isn't completely useless. It works great against blue Counterspell decks. It's also good to get all other decks to use their tricks early way before combat so that you don't have to expect any funny business when you attack. It also ruins cards like Righteousness that only work for blockers.

This card is fundamentally changed with the new rules, but it's not useless. If someone EVER holds a land open, and takes damage from this card, they just told you, "attack me and see what happens". Knowing this you can even use that towards your advantage and play mind games with your opponent by bluffing, and taking 1 or 2 damage every now and then.

If anything this cards flavor has increased tenfold from the 2010 rules change. It's red. It's anti blue. It creates a chaotic mind bender of a mini game full of lies. Toss this in a life gain deck, and you can have some serious fun bluffing your opponent out of attacking, or even from casting their good spells. This is a card that requires a poker face. I'm giving this 5/5

24643: Citadel of Pain.author: LordRandomness
24643: Citadel of Pain.text_parsed:
superboi has an excellent point. With mana burn around players could leave mana open and make the reasonable claim that their hand had nothing to cast and they therefore had no choice but to take the damage. Now leaving mana open with this on the field has only two reasons: The player has instants or other effects to make use of off-turn, or the player is pretending to have instants or other effects to make use of off-turn. Good luck figuring out which.

For the upper hand in these bluffing games, have an ability on the board that needs mana and should obviously be used off-turn. That gives you a reason to leave stuff untapped and makes people less likely to question your motives.

24645: Veteran Brawlers.author: Aquillion
24645: Veteran Brawlers.text_parsed:
People are underestimating this card. In a fast red deck, it's incredibly powerful.

If your opponent taps out, it kills them very very quickly when backed by other fast red damage cards.

If your opponent doesn't tap out, they're playing behind the curve and the rest of your deck will kill them just fine -- in that situation, this is effectively a two-mana stone rain, denying them a land for the rest of the game (or at least the parts of it a red deck should care about).

It's weak against blue control, but otherwise it's pretty strong. Another red or green deck that isn't tapping out in its first few turns is effectively dead anyway.
24645: Veteran Brawlers.text_posted:

It's weak against blue control, but otherwise it's pretty strong.  Another red or green deck that isn't tapping out in its first few turns is effectively dead anyway.

24645: Veteran Brawlers.author: RaymondKHessel

When these guys hit the field, your opponent has some tough decisions to make. Those who have commented before me have hit the nail on the head: does your opponent deal with a 4/4 attacker in the early game and "keep up" in land/mana tempo, or fall behind to avoid the attack? Either way, you derive advantage.

And, c'mon, 2 cmc for a red 4/4? That should always merit some attention from a red mage.

24654: Spore Frog.author: Zulp
24654: Spore Frog.text_parsed:
I remember this card from way back in the day when I was a little kid and didn't really play Magic, but my older friend did, and let me look through his binders and binders of cards. This card for some reason resonated with me. I didn't really understand the activated ability or the power of the card or anything like that, but I saw the art and read the flavor text, and they had at least a small effect on me, for the better.

And, as an aside, it's exceptionally effective mechanics-wise, too. Fog on demand works for me.

24654: Spore Frog.text_parsed:
Fantastic common that can fit into many different green decks. I'd say it is loads better then Haze Frog. The only real downside to this is that the opponent will see the fog effect coming. They might spend removal to get rid of it, but again, spending removal on a one drop seems like a waste.

Who knows, this might even save you during late game, giving you the turn you need to win. Stranger things have happened in magic.

24655: Silt Crawler.author: Ideatog
24655: Silt Crawler.text_parsed: Since the loss of mana burn, this little fella really has no downside since you can just tap all of your lands for mana first and not worry about overage. Unless you need an instant next turn, which in green means no combat tricks. Not that bad. The downside on an otherwise vanilla 3/3 for 3 is a creature type tax, since beasts have some pretty nifty tribal effects, notably Feral Throwback, Krosan Warchief, and Ravenous Baloth.

24658: Thresher Beast.author: raptorman333
24658: Thresher Beast.text_parsed: I don't get how this card is sub-par to Deus of Calamity. They virtually do the same thing, yet the trigger for this is much more enticing--block or sac... as opposed to block and it won't get sacked. Yea, I get that a 5 mana drop for a 6/6 with trample is better than for a 4/4 with no trample at the same cost, but unless you're playing mono red, mono green, or R/G, then the Deus is useless to you do to restrictions in casting cost. Think about it this way too, Thresher beast was in a extended with the Urza's block... meaning a Rancor drop makes this guy just That much better. Now I've got a 6/4 trample with block and you can kiss your land good-bye and probably your creature too... and, perhaps, STILL take damage! I'm aware there's a whole bunch of goodies around the sets the Deus was released in, but all in all, can i get the same rating on the two of them?! They both do their part equally and there's plenty of ways to pump a creature up or give it trample at a reasonable cost, especially with green.

24661: Wild Might.author: Silverware

Very strong early game, 2cmc +5/+5 until end of turn at instant speed is very good, very little can go wrong with this card, just wait till your opponents are tapped out and make sure your creature isn't blocked and in most cases your paying 2 for 5 damage. Even if your opponent pays the 2 you still get a +1/+1 until end of turn.

24661: Wild Might.author: feeble2002
24661: Wild Might.text_parsed:
This is a great card early game. Often during the first few turns your opponent will be tapped out playing spells. It provides +5/+5 as an instant. Even during the mid-game you should be able to sneak this ability in. It is only during extended games, after several turns, that it becomes a concern. In summary, it works superb in fast decks that aim to finish the opponent before he ramps up land. In legacy T1.5 it is useable.
The only deck color that presents a challenge is blue, which tend to have untapped land.

And Monstrous Growth is not an instant, a huge disadvantage.

If Giant Growth is a 4.5/5.0, this is a 4.0/5.0. Very solid in the right decks.

24661: Wild Might.author: Stinga
24661: Wild Might.text_parsed: I run this in a ghetto casual sligh R/G deck. I know that sounds kinda bad but hear me out. Lets say they go first. They drop a tapped dual-land. You do land reckless waif. Turn two they either A: do something, or don't do something. If B the waif flips and you wade in, killing their onedrop or smacking them pretty hard. If they don't do something they don't have two mana and Wild Might makes em take six. The great thing about the card is that, even in the worst case scenario, makes my nettle sentinel/goblin guide/whatever trade with a bear. It does not overkill sure, but in many many scenarios this is just as good as giant growth (assuming you don't trample).

It's still overpriced though. 4/5

People often play spells after you have to fog, so playing this for its alternate cost might even convince your opponent to just pass the turn after combat without playing anything :D

Supposedly, almost all tournament players didn't utilize this set but it was a pretty big hit with casual players, due to all the avatars. That's what I read anyway. I personally like the mechanic of the Avatars, it's something you don't see much of at all. But I'm pretty much just a casual player too, so who knows haha. I give it a four for the usability over the other avatars (BESIDES AVATAR OF WOE). It seems to me that this card is the easiest to use it's mana cost reduction in a one on one game. Especially against a saproling or other counter deck. In multiplayer though, my babycakes Avatar of Woe is the Master!!

24672: Squirrel Wrangler.author: majinara
24672: Squirrel Wrangler.text_parsed:
He's not awesome but not bad either. Best of course in combination with other squirrel cards. There, sacrificing a land to double your squirrels damage is great. You could also sacrifice, for example, four of your lands if you have the mana, to turn your squirrels into 5/5s. Sure, you would lose 4 lands, but who cares if you win.
The ability to sac lands to create tokens ain't bad either. If you have 6 mana, you could sac two lands at the end of your opponents turn to create four tokens, and in your turn sac two lands to give those tokens +2/+2. That's then 15 damage if the wrangler attacks too.

24675: Mungha Wurm.author: Cyberium
24675: Mungha Wurm.text_parsed:
Green is the color of mana, and often time mana from creatures. Some artifact also provide mana. Why are people so concerned with the drawback? Spoiled by power creeping, no doubt.

People who give this card a low rating had never tried Winter Orb or Armageddon strategies before (look up those cards if you haven't). It's common for green to utilize mana control strategies because green is least affected by mana restrain. If you can shut down all mana sources, a 6/5 on the field will almost always ram its head through.

24677: Vitalizing Wind.author: OpenSeasonNoobs
24677: Vitalizing Wind.text_parsed: Yeah, what all you clowns that are saying Titanic Ultimatum and Overrun are better (And now Overwhelming Stampede) are forgetting is that little word on this card INSTANT that allows you to do this AFTER BLOCKERS ARE DECLARED. This card is insane, and green ramps SO MUCH that it is very, very, VERY easy to get 9 mana with green. Use your saved up Omnath mana for it if you want, drop omnath 9 then replace it with a +7/+7 AND EVERY OTHER CREATURE YOU HAVE. This card is bar none the best green field pump in the game and you're a moron if you think otherwise, overrun and titanic ultimatum give your opponents the opportunity to predict what is coming that turn and tap your creatures before attackers are declared. This card is at the very least on par with Titanic Ultimatum and Overrun. Maybe not Overwhelming Stampede, but the fact that this card is an instant is BEAUTIFUL.

Use your saved up Omnath mana for it if you want, drop omnath 9 then replace it with a +7/+7 AND EVERY OTHER CREATURE YOU HAVE. This card is bar none the best green field pump in the game and you're a moron if you think otherwise, overrun and titanic ultimatum give your opponents the opportunity to predict what is coming that turn and tap your creatures before attackers are declared. This card is at the very least on par with Titanic Ultimatum and Overrun. Maybe not Overwhelming Stampede, but the fact that this card is an instant is BEAUTIFUL.

@OpenSeasonNoobs:
"Oh, my opponent left NINE mana open, and now attacks with all creatures. I wonder what he might be up to.
Certainly nothing insidious. Probably he just wants me to use my removal spell of one on his attacking creatures, so he can cast a Krosan Colossus after combat. Ha, i won't fall for that! Now at first i think i'll just leave a bunch of his smaller creatures unblocked and take the tad of damage..."

There are lots of better finishers of that kind.

Oh yeah, the days were you just played with your crappy decks against friends with other crappy decks and from time to time used to have ridiculously long matches. 24677: Vitalizing Wind.author: KramlmarK
24677: Vitalizing Wind.text_parsed:
@People saying 9 open mana is suspicious:

I don't know what your playgroup looks like, but in mine, we play our spells second main unless we have a good reason not to. This is both good strategy and common practice in competitive magic. Going to attacks with all your mana open is the norm, not the exception. Sure, attacking with your saprolings into their anything might hint that something's up, but it could just as easily be a Skarrg Goliath (or might of Oaks, if your comment predates Gatecrash), in which case blocking is exactly what you want them to do. And even if they do know it's coming they...block to stop themselves from dying? Last I checked, bonfire of the damned was a good card.

It's completely unplayable in competitive constructed (by virtue of its cost), sure, but nobody is seriously suggesting this card for constructed. It's great in EDH tokens and/or creature swarm, which is exactly where it goes. Niche card, but good one.

24677: Vitalizing Wind.author: Ferlord
24677: Vitalizing Wind.text_parsed:
In terms of boosting, this card gets some bonus scattergory points for being an instant, but without trample, it might not make a difference.

If you are looking for an instant-speed "Overrun" effect, play Kamahl, Fist of Krosa. You get trample, can do it as many times as you want (per increment of mana), and you can turn your lands into creatures for creatures to receive the boost. This can double-up as a "get out of a boardwipe-free" card, since you can then turn their lands into creatures.

But if you don't have much green (Comparably, 2 Kamahl-Overruns costs and gives +6/+6 and trample), this is a much more effective alternative.

24678: Dual Nature.author: Prizrak
24678: Dual Nature.text_parsed:
Okay, this is head-hurty, but I think it works.

You have a Blisterstick Shaman and Dual Nature in play.
You play Changeling Titan, also getting a Titantoken
The Titan champions the Shaman
The Titantoken champions the Titan, and you get your Shaman back and a Shamantoken (2 damage to opponent)
Since the Titan left play, the Titantoken does as well
Since the Titantoken left play, you get your Titan back (since it was the champion target)
It comes into play along with a new Titantoken
Repeat for infinite damage.
Offer headache medication to opponent.

24679: Hollow Warrior.author: TDL

It's powercreep, but I don't think anyone played this card in anything but limited decks anyway. Hollow Warrior does have some neat flavor, though.

24682: Copper-Leaf Angel.author: Mode

For 5 mana, why would you want an initially small creature that's prone to removal, takes an additional turn to get big, and still asks you to dump most of your lands for it? Your opponent can even kill her before she gets the counters!

This is a terrible beater.
Sure, Baneslayer Angels weren't a thing back then. But Serra Angel definitely was.
And Rathi Dragon, which is basically this minus the suck.

It's actually a functionally interesting high risk, high reward card. But the problem with this card is the casting cost. This should have been a in that top right corner.

24685: Rhystic Cave.text_parsed: No, the rules on the card overrule the actual game rules, so they can react to it.
24685: Rhystic Cave.text_posted: No, the rules on the card overrule the actual game rules, so they can react to it.

24685: Rhystic Cave.author: Chaikov
24685: Rhystic Cave.text_parsed:
-This card works differently from other »variable RHYSTIC»: it is the only one having you announce your choice FIRST (color) and THEN opponents get to pay or not.
-This represents strategic information.
-With the other «variable RHYSTIC» (Mystic Remora, Rhystic Circle, Rhystic Study), opponents decide whether or not to pay FIRST, and THEN you make your decision.
-(«Non-variable RHYSTIC» include no hidden choice.)
24685: Rhystic Cave.text_posted:

24685: Rhystic Cave.author: Paolino
24685: Rhystic Cave.text_parsed:
This card is not as bad as it seems at first glance: in a control deck you can force opponent to use his/her mana to prevent you casting your spells; moreover it gives you ANY color of mana, so that you can cheat about your colored mana needs (for example, you ask for green and you don't have any other green mana, opponent pays to prevent you have this mana, but you cast another nongreen spell and opponent can't cast his/her counter anymore because he/she doesn't have enough mana). I think this is the intent this card was designed to. It's not Reflecting Pool or City of Brass, but it doesn't pretend to be!
Last thing: GREAT ARTWORK! Rob Alexander rulez!

24685: Rhystic Cave.author: Eddie_Antilles
24685: Rhystic Cave.text_parsed:
A good land for a control player; if you are playing your deck right, YOU should be controlling the flow of the game and they shouldn't have the opportunity to prevent the mana. Also great for playing mind games with your opponent as @Paolino said.

Finally, it's almost like a Rishadan Port that your opponent decides to use ON THEMSELVES. Great for Lulz...

3.5/5

24685: Rhystic Cave.author: EnPassant
24685: Rhystic Cave.text_parsed:
This card gets way too bad of a rep. In multicolored green / blue/ red, where early play is the key to midgame setup, this card plays brilliantly. It plays the earlygame variance to run ANY mana near-guaranteed on the first turn.

Run with 4 Llanowar Elves and a few Joiner Adepts (or abundant growth), Gitaxian probe, Lightning bolt, and all of a sudden you have three color splash with one card, and your enemy can do nothing about it.

5/5 earlygame, and when you can successfully run EG red / green / blue, the rest doesn't matter

24686: Noxious Field.author: Equinox523
24686: Noxious Field.text_parsed: While Pestilence may initially seem like the closest comparison, the tapping nature of this makes it so that you cannot trigger this multiple times without having more than one copy (or untapping tricks). While it can be a mini-board wipe, it's worth noting that it makes your hand a colorless source of damage, which deals with pesky creatures with Protection from Black or circumvents Circle of Protection: Black.
